title: Song of Solomon Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Song of Solomon chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Song of Solomon Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is described as better than wine in Song of Solomon 1:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy love
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:2 states, 'for thy love is better than wine.'

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:3, why do the virgins love the speaker's beloved?
options: Because of the savour of his good ointments
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the savour of his good ointments
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:3 says, 'Because of the savour of thy good ointments thy name is as ointment poured forth, therefore do the virgins love thee.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:4, where has the king brought the speaker?
questions.correctAnswer: Into his chambers
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:4 states, 'the king hath brought me into his chambers.'

questions.question: How does the speaker describe herself in Song of Solomon 1:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Black but comely
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:5 says, 'I am black, but comely, O ye daughters of Jerusalem.'

questions.question: Why does the speaker say not to look upon her, according to Song of Solomon 1:6?
options: Because she is black from the sun
questions.correctAnswer: Because she is black from the sun
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:6 says, 'Look not upon me, because I am black, because the sun hath looked upon me.'

questions.question: What task were the speaker's mother's children angry about in Song of Solomon 1:6?
options: Making her the keeper of the vineyards
questions.correctAnswer: Making her the keeper of the vineyards
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:6 states, 'my mother's children were angry with me; they made me the keeper of the vineyards.'

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:7, what does the speaker ask about the one whom her soul loves?
options: Where he feedeth and maketh his flock to rest at noon
questions.correctAnswer: Where he feedeth and maketh his flock to rest at noon
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:7 says, 'Tell me, O thou whom my soul loveth, where thou feedest, where thou makest thy flock to rest at noon.'

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:8, where should the fairest among women feed her kids?
questions.correctAnswer: Beside the shepherds' tents
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:8 instructs, 'go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock, and feed thy kids beside the shepherds' tents.'

questions.question: What is the beloved compared to in Song of Solomon 1:9?
options: A company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots
questions.correctAnswer: A company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:9 states, 'I have compared thee, O my love, to a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots.'

questions.question: What adorns the cheeks and neck of the beloved in Song of Solomon 1:10?
options: Rows of jewels and chains of gold
questions.correctAnswer: Rows of jewels and chains of gold
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:10 says, 'Thy cheeks are comely with rows of jewels, thy neck with chains of gold.'

questions.question: Which precious metals are mentioned as making borders in Song of Solomon 1:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Gold and silver
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:11 states, 'We will make thee borders of gold with studs of silver.'

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 1:12 mentions that the king is standing at his table while the spikenard sends forth its smell.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:12 says, 'While the king sitteth at his table, my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.' The king is sitting, not standing.

questions.question: True or False: According to Song of Solomon 1:13, the beloved lies all night betwixt the speaker's breasts.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:13 states, 'he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'My beloved is unto me as a cluster of ______ in the vineyards of Engedi.' (Song of Solomon 1:14)
questions.correctAnswer: camphire
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:14 says, 'My beloved is unto me as a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of Engedi.'

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 1:15 describes the beloved as having doves' eyes.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:15 says, 'Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves' eyes.'

medium.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Song of Solomon Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 1:2 teach us about expressing love and affection in marriage?
options: Love is sweeter than wine and should be expressed openly
Love is secret and should not be revealed
Love is less important than wealth
Love should be controlled and limited
questions.correctAnswer: Love is sweeter than wine and should be expressed openly
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:2 says, 'Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.' This shows the importance of expressing love and affection openly in marriage. Related verses: 1:4, 1:15, 1:16.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of rejection and low self-worth. Based on Song of Solomon 1:5-6, what biblical truth would you share to encourage humility and contentment?
options: Your value is not determined by others' opinions but by God's love
You should isolate yourself to avoid rejection
You must prove your worth by work alone
questions.correctAnswer: Your value is not determined by others' opinions but by God's love
questions.explanation: In 1:5-6, the speaker acknowledges being 'black, but comely' despite rejection by others. This teaches humility and contentment in God's eyes over human judgment. Supporting verses: 1:3, 1:4, 1:15.

questions.question: What does Song of Solomon 1:4 teach about the joy and gladness found in trusting and remembering God's love?
options: Trusting God's love brings rejoicing and gladness
Rejoicing is only for perfect people
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God's love brings rejoicing and gladness
questions.explanation: Verse 1:4 shows 'we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine.' This emphasizes that trust in God's love leads to joy and gladness. Related verses: 1:2, 1:3, 1:15.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 1:7 encourage believers to seek fellowship and guidance in their spiritual walk?
options: Ask and seek where your beloved feeds and rests to find guidance
Depend only on your own wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Ask and seek where your beloved feeds and rests to find guidance
questions.explanation: In 1:7, the speaker asks, 'Tell me... where thou feedest... where thou makest thy flock to rest,' illustrating the importance of seeking fellowship and spiritual guidance. Supporting verses: 1:8, 1:9, 1:13.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:9-11, how can the beauty and adornment of a believer reflect spiritual discipline and integrity?
options: Spiritual beauty is like jewels and gold adorning a faithful life
Physical beauty is all that matters
Adornment should be avoided in faith
Spiritual discipline is unrelated to outward appearance
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual beauty is like jewels and gold adorning a faithful life
questions.explanation: Verses 1:9-11 compare love to horses, cheeks to jewels, and neck to gold chains, symbolizing that spiritual discipline and integrity beautify a believer’s life. Related verses: 1:10, 1:11, 1:15.

questions.question: How can Song of Solomon 1:12-13 inspire personal devotion and prayer life?
options: Like spikenard and myrrh, devotion should be fragrant and continual
Prayer should be infrequent and brief
Devotion is only for public display
questions.correctAnswer: Like spikenard and myrrh, devotion should be fragrant and continual
questions.explanation: Verses 1:12-13 describe spikenard and myrrh’s fragrance, symbolizing a devotion that is pleasing and constant in prayer and personal worship. Supporting verses: 1:14, 1:15, 1:16.

questions.question: What biblical virtue related to marriage is highlighted in Song of Solomon 1:13 where the beloved lies 'betwixt my breasts'?
options: Intimacy and mutual affection in marriage
questions.correctAnswer: Intimacy and mutual affection in marriage
questions.explanation: Verse 1:13 illustrates close intimacy and affection between spouses as a biblical virtue to nurture marriage. See also 1:2, 1:15, 1:16.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 1:14 demonstrate the importance of appreciating and valuing one’s spouse?
options: The beloved is compared to a cluster of camphire, showing admiration
Spouses should ignore each other’s qualities
Value is based on external achievements only
Marriage is a burden to be endured
questions.correctAnswer: The beloved is compared to a cluster of camphire, showing admiration
questions.explanation: In 1:14, the beloved is likened to fragrant camphire, teaching believers to appreciate and value their spouse’s qualities. Supporting verses: 1:10, 1:15, 1:16.

questions.question: A Christian is struggling to persevere through trials. Based on Song of Solomon 1:4, what encouragement can you give about remembering God’s love?
options: Remembering God’s love brings strength and joy amid trials
Trials mean God has abandoned you
Forget God’s love to focus on the problem
Trials should be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Remembering God’s love brings strength and joy amid trials
questions.explanation: Verse 1:4 says 'we will remember thy love more than wine,' encouraging believers to find joy and strength in God’s love during hardships. Related verses: 1:2, 1:3, 1:5.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 1:6 teach about humility and honesty in confessing personal shortcomings?
options: The speaker admits not keeping her own vineyard, showing humility
questions.correctAnswer: The speaker admits not keeping her own vineyard, showing humility
questions.explanation: In 1:6, the speaker humbly admits failure to keep her vineyard, modeling honesty and humility before God and others. See also 1:5, 1:7, 1:8.

questions.question: True or False: Song of Solomon 1:15 describes the beloved as having eyes like doves, symbolizing purity and gentleness in relationships.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 1:15 says, 'thou hast doves' eyes,' symbolizing purity, gentleness, and trustworthiness in the beloved’s character, important virtues in relationships.

questions.question: True or False: According to Song of Solomon 1:16, the couple's bed is described as green, symbolizing freshness and vitality in their union.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 1:16 states 'our bed is green,' symbolizing renewal, vitality, and life in their relationship, encouraging believers to nurture their marriage.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Song of Solomon 1:17 says, 'The beams of our house are _____, and our rafters of fir.'
questions.correctAnswer: cedar
questions.explanation: Verse 1:17 specifically mentions 'The beams of our house are cedar,' symbolizing strength and durability, encouraging building a strong spiritual and family foundation.

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 1:3 illustrate the importance of a good reputation and integrity in the community?
options: A good name is like ointment that draws love and respect
Reputation is unimportant in community life
Love is unrelated to one’s name
questions.correctAnswer: A good name is like ointment that draws love and respect
questions.explanation: Verse 1:3 states, 'thy name is as ointment poured forth, therefore do the virgins love thee,' illustrating that integrity and reputation attract love and respect. Related verses: 1:4, 1:5, 1:6.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:8, what practical advice is given to those seeking to follow and serve faithfully in the community of faith?
options: Follow the footsteps of the flock and serve alongside others
questions.correctAnswer: Follow the footsteps of the flock and serve alongside others
questions.explanation: Verse 1:8 advises to 'go thy way forth by the footsteps of the flock,' encouraging believers to serve faithfully with the community. Supporting verses: 1:7, 1:9, 1:10.

hard.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Song of Solomon Chapter 1.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'The song of songs' in Song of Solomon 1:1 from a Hebrew literary perspective?
options: It denotes the greatest or most excellent song
It is a title indicating a collection of songs
It is a metaphor for the Messiah's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes the greatest or most excellent song
questions.explanation: The phrase 'The song of songs' is a Hebrew superlative indicating the greatest or most excellent song, marking the book's supreme poetic status (Song of Solomon 1:1).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:2, the beloved says, 'for thy love is better than wine.' What Old Testament theme does this evoke?
options: God’s covenant love surpassing worldly pleasures
The wisdom of Proverbs about temperance
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant love surpassing worldly pleasures
questions.explanation: The comparison of love to wine echoes biblical themes where God’s covenant love (hesed) is portrayed as more desirable than physical pleasures, paralleling Psalms and Hosea’s expressions of divine love (Song of Solomon 1:2).

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Song of Solomon 1:3 when it says, 'thy name is as ointment poured forth'?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The comparison using 'as' in 'thy name is as ointment poured forth' is a simile, a common Hebrew poetic device to convey sensory imagery (Song of Solomon 1:3).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:4, the invitation to 'run after thee' and 'be glad and rejoice' reflects which cultural or ritual context of the Ancient Near East?
questions.correctAnswer: Royal wedding celebrations
questions.explanation: The joy and invitation to 'run after thee' and rejoice reflect imagery associated with royal wedding festivities in the Ancient Near East, highlighting nuptial themes (Song of Solomon 1:4).

questions.question: The speaker in Song of Solomon 1:5 describes herself as 'black, but comely.' What historical or cultural significance does this have in the context of the ancient Near East?
options: Indicating sun exposure due to outdoor labor
questions.correctAnswer: Indicating sun exposure due to outdoor labor
questions.explanation: The description of being 'black' because of sun exposure is culturally significant, reflecting the social reality of women working outdoors, often overlooked in royal or courtly love poetry (Song of Solomon 1:5-6).

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:6, why was the speaker made 'the keeper of the vineyards' by her mother's children?
options: As a mark of honor and responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Because of jealousy and exclusion
questions.explanation: The verse indicates jealousy and exclusion by her siblings, assigning her to vineyard keeper duties as a form of marginalization (Song of Solomon 1:6).

questions.question: What is the significance of the shepherd imagery in Song of Solomon 1:7-8 in relation to Old Testament typology?
options: It reflects the role of God as the Good Shepherd
It alludes to the Exodus journey
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the role of God as the Good Shepherd
questions.explanation: The shepherd imagery parallels Old Testament typology where God and the Messiah are depicted as shepherds caring for their flock, bringing foreshadowing to New Testament understandings (Song of Solomon 1:7-8).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:9, the beloved is compared to 'a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots.' What is the likely cultural meaning of this metaphor?
options: Power and majesty associated with Egyptian chariots
questions.correctAnswer: Power and majesty associated with Egyptian chariots
questions.explanation: Pharaoh’s chariots symbolize royal power and grandeur in the ancient Near East; comparing the beloved to these horses highlights strength and majesty (Song of Solomon 1:9).

questions.question: What does the description of 'rows of jewels' on cheeks and 'chains of gold' on the neck in Song of Solomon 1:10 indicate about ancient Near Eastern beauty standards?
options: Adornment with precious metals and stones was a sign of beauty and status
Natural beauty was preferred over adornment
Modesty forbade the use of jewelry
Jewelry was only worn by priests
questions.correctAnswer: Adornment with precious metals and stones was a sign of beauty and status
questions.explanation: The detailed description of jewelry reflects ancient Near Eastern customs where adornment with gold and jewels symbolized beauty, wealth, and social standing (Song of Solomon 1:10).

questions.question: Song of Solomon 1:12 mentions 'my spikenard sendeth forth the smell thereof.' What is the significance of spikenard in biblical and cultural contexts?
options: It represents costly and fragrant ointment used in worship and love
It is a bitter herb used for cleansing
It is a staple food grain
It is a type of musical instrument
questions.correctAnswer: It represents costly and fragrant ointment used in worship and love
questions.explanation: Spikenard is a costly perfume used both in worship and intimate settings, symbolizing preciousness and devotion, as also seen in New Testament anointing stories (Song of Solomon 1:12).

questions.question: The phrase 'he shall lie all night betwixt my breasts' in Song of Solomon 1:13 uses which type of poetic imagery common in Hebrew love poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: Intimate and protective imagery
questions.explanation: This intimate expression uses protective and affectionate imagery typical of Hebrew love poetry, emphasizing closeness and tenderness (Song of Solomon 1:13).

questions.question: Song of Solomon 1:14 compares the beloved to 'a cluster of camphire in the vineyards of Engedi.' What is the significance of Engedi in biblical geography and symbolism?
options: Engedi was an oasis symbolizing beauty and fertility
It was a city of refuge for outcasts
It was the site of Solomon’s temple
It was a desert associated with wilderness testing
questions.correctAnswer: Engedi was an oasis symbolizing beauty and fertility
questions.explanation: Engedi is a fertile oasis near the Dead Sea, often associated with lushness and beauty, making the metaphor a symbol of vitality and desirability (Song of Solomon 1:14).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:15, the beloved is said to have 'doves' eyes.' What does this metaphor typically symbolize in Hebrew poetry?
questions.correctAnswer: Purity and gentleness
questions.explanation: Doves are biblical symbols of purity, innocence, and gentleness, so 'doves' eyes' suggest tender and pure beauty (Song of Solomon 1:15).

questions.question: The description of 'The beams of our house are cedar, and our rafters of fir' in Song of Solomon 1:17 reflects what about ancient Near Eastern architecture and symbolism?
options: Use of durable and fragrant wood symbolizing strength and stability
questions.correctAnswer: Use of durable and fragrant wood symbolizing strength and stability
questions.explanation: Cedar and fir were valued for durability and aroma, used in important buildings symbolizing strength and permanence (Song of Solomon 1:17).

questions.question: True or False: The speaker in Song of Solomon 1:6 admits to successfully keeping her own vineyard despite her siblings’ anger.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The speaker admits she has not kept her own vineyard, indicating a failure or neglect despite being keeper of the vineyards assigned by her siblings (Song of Solomon 1:6).

theological.title: Song of Solomon Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Song of Solomon Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the song of songs' in Song of Solomon 1:1?
options: It indicates the greatest of all songs
It refers to a collection of many songs
It means a song about the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates the greatest of all songs
questions.explanation: The phrase 'song of songs' in Song of Solomon 1:1 means 'the greatest song' or 'the best of songs,' emphasizing the supreme nature of this poetic work. This superlative form is consistent with other biblical superlatives such as 'king of kings' (1 Timothy 6:15) and 'Lord of lords' (Revelation 17:14), which denote supremacy.

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:2, to what is the beloved's love compared?
questions.correctAnswer: Wine
questions.explanation: In Song of Solomon 1:2, the beloved's love is said to be better than wine, highlighting its sweetness, joy, and intoxicating effect. This metaphor aligns with biblical imagery where wine symbolizes blessing and joy (Psalm 104:15; John 2:1-11).

questions.question: What reason does the woman give for her dark complexion in Song of Solomon 1:6?
options: Because the sun hath looked upon me
Because I have been in mourning
Because I have been in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because the sun hath looked upon me
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:6 explains the woman's dark complexion as a result of sun exposure, symbolizing her labor and hardship. This imagery points to human toil and suffering, echoing themes of human brokenness and the fallen condition (Genesis 3:17-19; Luke 12:47-48).

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:4, what is the response of the speaker to the king bringing her into his chambers?
options: They will be glad and rejoice
questions.correctAnswer: They will be glad and rejoice
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:4 expresses joy and gladness in response to being brought into the king’s chambers, symbolizing intimacy and covenant love. This joy reflects the eschatological union between Christ and His bride, the church (Revelation 19:7; Isaiah 62:5).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'thy name is as ointment poured forth' in Song of Solomon 1:3 symbolize?
options: The sweet and powerful reputation of the beloved
The smell of the temple incense
questions.correctAnswer: The sweet and powerful reputation of the beloved
questions.explanation: In Song of Solomon 1:3, the beloved’s name is likened to ointment poured forth, symbolizing the spread of a fragrant and powerful reputation. This reflects the biblical theme of God's name being exalted and fragrant before His people (Psalm 45:7; Exodus 30:22-33; 1 Samuel 16:13).

questions.question: What does the woman request in Song of Solomon 1:7 concerning the beloved's whereabouts?
options: Where he feeds and makes his flock to rest
questions.correctAnswer: Where he feeds and makes his flock to rest
questions.explanation: In Song of Solomon 1:7, the woman inquires about where her beloved tends his flock, symbolizing her desire to be near him and to share in his care and provision. This pastoral imagery resonates with Christ as the Good Shepherd (John 10:11) and the church as His flock (Psalm 23).

questions.question: How is the beloved described in Song of Solomon 1:9?
options: Like a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots
Like a lion in the forest
Like a dove upon the waters
questions.correctAnswer: Like a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:9 compares the beloved to a company of horses in Pharaoh's chariots, symbolizing strength, majesty, and royal power. This connects to messianic imagery of the king coming in power (Psalm 45:3-5; Zechariah 10:3; Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'spikenard' mentioned in Song of Solomon 1:12?
options: It signifies fragrant devotion and intimate worship
It refers to a medicinal herb
It is a type of royal garment
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies fragrant devotion and intimate worship
questions.explanation: The spikenard in Song of Solomon 1:12 symbolizes fragrant devotion and intimate worship. This is consistent with Mary anointing Jesus with spikenard (John 12:3), representing costly love and sacrificial honor.

questions.question: In Song of Solomon 1:13, the beloved is compared to what fragrant item?
questions.correctAnswer: A bundle of myrrh
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:13 compares the beloved to a bundle of myrrh, a precious perfume associated with burial and sacrifice (John 19:39), thus foreshadowing Christ's sacrificial death and His intimate presence to the believer.

questions.question: What does the green bed in Song of Solomon 1:16 symbolize in biblical theology?
questions.correctAnswer: Life, renewal, and covenantal intimacy
questions.explanation: The green bed in Song of Solomon 1:16 symbolizes life, renewal, and covenantal intimacy, reflecting biblical themes where green denotes flourishing life (Psalm 23:2; Ezekiel 37:9) and the intimate union between Christ and His bride.

questions.question: What is the emotional tone expressed in Song of Solomon 1:15 when describing the beloved's eyes?
questions.correctAnswer: Tenderness and admiration
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:15 describes the beloved’s eyes as doves’ eyes, conveying tenderness and admiration. This imagery is consistent with biblical metaphors where doves symbolize purity, gentleness, and the Spirit (Matthew 3:16; Song of Solomon 5:12).

questions.question: What does the woman confess about her own vineyard in Song of Solomon 1:6?
options: She has not kept her own vineyard
She has protected her vineyard well
Her vineyard is a place of rest
questions.correctAnswer: She has not kept her own vineyard
questions.explanation: In Song of Solomon 1:6, the woman admits she has not kept her own vineyard, symbolizing a failure to guard her own purity or well-being. This echoes themes of human sin and need for stewardship (Genesis 2:15; Isaiah 5:1-7).

questions.question: According to Song of Solomon 1:10, how is the beloved’s appearance described?
options: Cheeks comely with rows of jewels and neck with chains of gold
questions.correctAnswer: Cheeks comely with rows of jewels and neck with chains of gold
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:10 describes the beloved’s beauty with jewels and gold, symbolizing glory and honor. This reflects the biblical portrayal of the Messiah’s glory and honor (Isaiah 61:10; Revelation 21:11).

questions.question: What architectural materials are mentioned in Song of Solomon 1:17 for the beams and rafters of the house?
questions.correctAnswer: Cedar and fir
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:17 mentions cedar beams and fir rafters, materials associated with strength, durability, and beauty (1 Kings 5:6; Psalm 92:12). These materials symbolize the firm foundation of God's covenant house (Hebrews 3:6).

questions.question: How does Song of Solomon 1:14 describe the beloved in relation to the vineyards of Engedi?
questions.correctAnswer: As a cluster of camphire
questions.explanation: Song of Solomon 1:14 compares the beloved to a cluster of camphire (henna) in the vineyards of Engedi, symbolizing beauty, fertility, and delight. This aligns with biblical themes of the land’s fruitfulness and God's blessing (Genesis 49:10; Song of Solomon 4:13-14).
